text: hi everyone uh cookie recipe here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review this new Mars Volta
album itself titled this is the newest
and seventh full-length album from the
legendary progressive rock outfit The
Mars Volta their first record in 10
years which is a bit of a trip for me
because I reviewed their last album
nocturniket uh 10 years ago and for some
reason that record feels like it came
out way more recently though that can't
be right because there's been an ocean
of Omar Rodriguez Lopez solo stuff and
side work since then some with Cedric
there was also an at the drive-in
comeback but yeah for Volta it has been
a minute to say the least and it kind of
sounds like it despite Omar and Cedric
uh being pretty busy over the past 10
years meaning I think something's kind
of missing on this one to be frank the
band's personnel has really thinned out
over the years but I would say this is
the first project where it really sounds
like it now you would think that
wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing
especially since Omar and Cedric are
truly like the heart of the band and
also changes in Personnel didn't exactly
impact the equality of nocturnica but
man does The Mars Volta here sound like
Cedric and Omar recording on a
shoestring budget at home and don't get
me wrong a lot of great records and
songs have been recorded under those
circumstances I have reviewed quite a
few of them but in this instance I think
it's just resulted in a very dry sound
very dry album a very thin series of
mixes that don't bring the color the
lushness and the intensity The Mars
Volta is known for if anything the band
has been known to overdo it on things
like winding song structures
instrumental layers Cedric's vocal
effects but this album by comparison
feels kind of uh under developed and
lacking in detail not that I dislike the
more accessible direction of the
songwriting on this one the most
straightforward tracks ended up being
some of my favorites here like the 7 70s
Latin Rock Fusion of black light shine
with its subtly psychedelic guitars
Punchy hand drums and these Eerie vocal
harmonies from Cedric on the pre-chorus
there are a lot of bold elements on this
one there's also the Moody and Rockin
vigil which also sounds straight out of
the 70s the dramatic vocals and Serene
Keys woven throughout this track have
almost the vibe of a soft Rock ballad
but with kind of an eccentric flare
given that it is The Mars Volta then no
case gain has to be one of the grooviest
and most direct pop rock cuts the band's
ever recorded the intro on this track is
almost something I would expect from a
Foster the People record and if you'd
never see me again it'll be too soon
it's a great little song but herein lies
the issue the production is kind of
bland lifeless and a little sloppy I
don't know why Omar after so many years
of producing great sounding Mars Volta
records has allowed things to fall to
the Wayside this much in terms of color
and texture the drums have no punch the
guitar tones are absolutely run in the
the mill the base has no flavor the
layering is a little chaotic and frankly
not in an endearing way this could truly
be one of the band's best songs if the
sound of it wasn't so mid-grade now this
is kind of the most prominent issue with
the record and I think it reveals itself
more strongly on these softer Cuts where
you would hope for a prettier sound
palette to accompany the balladri going
on whether that beyond the song cerulea
or blank condolences kind of unfortunate
that these tracks do suffer with the
lack of interesting sound palettes that
they do because they do feature some of
the Most heart-wrenching lyrics that
Cedric has ever laid to a track yeah the
instrumentation just comes off so muddy
and flat boxed in but what's even more
of a head scratch on some of these
tracks is seemingly the band's inability
to write a proper ending for some of
these Cuts we have tracks where it's
kind of a cop out and the whole thing
just kind of ends off with like some
effects covering everything up we have
short story which sort of Fizzles out at
the Finish ish there's also flash burns
from flashbacks which when I first heard
it was a highlight for me because I
really do love the intense and linear
way with which the instrumentation
builds up but it's essentially a bridge
to nowhere as it goes higher and higher
and higher very gradually and then just
kind of cuts off out of nowhere then
what's with que dios te mardigo me
Corazon is this like an experiment of
the band trying to see if they can write
the boldest and sauciest track thus far
on the record but make it so short it's
completely ungratifying I do love that
true blue Latin Rock flavor coming
through on the instrumental but not much
else like I said these issues persist
throughout the lp though I do guess the
last leg of the record bring some
interesting moments there are a few sort
of mystical cuts that take the shape of
one tormaline which is a great tune and
has some beautiful acoustic guitar work
laced into it I think the Simplicity of
this one keeps it from being impacted by
these subpar mixes and sound play on
this thing then there's also the pragy
Equus 3 with these heavy and hip
hypnotic riffs and grooves on it it
sounds almost like Cedric singing on a
tool song and I draw that comparison in
the best way possible like something
right like from that opiate era but then
I'm kind of split past this point
collapsible shoulders with its darting
obnoxious vocal leads and Cedric's
accented spoken word bits uh yeah this
is easily the most unlikable and
annoying song on the entire record but I
suppose the requisition does Rock harder
than many of the other tracks and does
make for a strong finale for The LP but
yeah overall I just think this album is
okay no more no less it does have some
decent songs and songwriting at its core
but the sound the production uh the
performances are just not really there
they range from supremely subpar to uh
incredibly Bland there's not really a
moment on this record sonically I could
legitimately call Rich or impressive or
uh interesting especially when I am
thinking about uh how older Mars Volta
records even their last one used to
sound if anything I would call this
record a lesson learned in terms of how
exactly the sound of a piece of music
the recording can really take the wind
out of a song of sales I'm feeling a
light two decent six on this one
